articles.headline: Tensions Erupt at Los Angeles Times as Owner Weighs Deep Cuts
articles.snippet: The biggest news organization on the West Coast has been roiled by the potential layoffs of roughly 100 newsroom employees.
articles.abstract: The biggest news organization on the West Coast has been roiled by the potential layoffs of roughly 100 newsroom employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around twilight on Thursday, Los Angeles Times journalists gathered at Flora, a rooftop bar not far from the paper’s headquarters, to toast their departing editor, Kevin Merida.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson

articles.headline: Israel-E.U. Meeting on Gaza’s Future Yields Division and Confusion
articles.snippet: Europeans, insisting on Palestinian statehood, are frustrated by Israel’s opposition and lack of a postwar plan for the devastated Gaza Strip.
articles.abstract: Europeans, insisting on Palestinian statehood, are frustrated by Israel’s opposition and lack of a postwar plan for the devastated Gaza Strip.
articles.lead_paragraph: European foreign ministers pressed their Israeli counterpart on Monday to agree to the creation of a Palestinian state, in a meeting that left European diplomats bewildered about postwar Israeli plans for the Gaza Strip and reinforced the deep disconnect between Israel and much of the world.
articles.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Hiba Yazbek, Adam Rasgon, Monika Pronczuk and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: China’s Travel Economy Is Slowly Coming Back. Here’s Where It Stands.
articles.snippet: Over a year after China opened its borders following the pandemic, international trips are still lagging, although domestic travel is more popular.
articles.abstract: Over a year after China opened its borders following the pandemic, international trips are still lagging, although domestic travel is more popular.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since China reopened its borders in 2023 after three years of Covid isolation, domestic travel has thrived and high-speed rail has grown increasingly popular. But international trips in and out of the country are lagging, and flight capacity is still just two-thirds of prepandemic levels.

articles.headline: After a Botched Execution, Alabama Is Trying an Untested Method
articles.snippet: The state plans to carry out the first U.S. execution via nitrogen hypoxia with Kenneth Smith, who survived an earlier attempt to execute him by lethal injection.
articles.abstract: The state plans to carry out the first U.S. execution via nitrogen hypoxia with Kenneth Smith, who survived an earlier attempt to execute him by lethal injection.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was Nov. 17, 2022, and Kenneth Smith was lying on a gurney inside Alabama’s execution chamber, his arms and legs strapped down as he waited to be put to death. Mr. Smith, who had been on death row for more than a quarter-century after being convicted of murdering a woman, recalled thanking God for his final week alive and thinking of his family.

articles.headline: Jury to Decide if Mother of Michigan School Shooter Is Guilty, Too
articles.snippet: Jury selection began on Tuesday in the trial of Jennifer Crumbley, whose son, Ethan Crumbley, killed four students in 2021. In a rare move, prosecutors have charged both of his parents with involuntary manslaughter.
articles.abstract: Jury selection began on Tuesday in the trial of Jennifer Crumbley, whose son, Ethan Crumbley, killed four students in 2021. In a rare move, prosecutors have charged both of his parents with involuntary manslaughter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Frequently left home alone, Ethan Crumbley texted his mother in March 2021 that he had seen a demon in their house, one that hurled dishes across the kitchen. Days later, his parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, discussed how their teenage son was “worked up and agitated,” weighing whether to give him Xanax.

articles.headline: Stripped, Beaten or Vanished: Israel’s Treatment of Gaza Detainees Raises Alarm
articles.snippet: A U.N. office said Israel’s detention and treatment of detainees might amount to torture. It estimated thousands had been detained and held in “horrific” conditions. Some were freed wearing only diapers.
articles.abstract: A U.N. office said Israel’s detention and treatment of detainees might amount to torture. It estimated thousands had been detained and held in “horrific” conditions. Some were freed wearing only diapers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Cold, almost naked and surrounded by Israeli soldiers with M16 assault rifles, Ayman Lubbad knelt among dozens of Palestinian men and boys who had just been forced from their homes in northern Gaza.

articles.headline: Why China Has Lost Interest in Hollywood Movies
articles.snippet: No American films ranked among the 10 highest grossing in China last year as viewers who once flocked to foreign blockbusters continued to disappear.
articles.abstract: No American films ranked among the 10 highest grossing in China last year as viewers who once flocked to foreign blockbusters continued to disappear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before the sequel to “Aquaman” was released in China last month, Warner Bros. did everything it could to sustain the original movie’s success.
articles.byline: By Claire Fu, Brooks Barnes and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Netflix to Stream W.W.E.’s ‘Raw’ in $5 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The weekly wrestling program will move to Netflix in 2025 as part of a 10-year agreement, a big leap into live events for the streaming platform.
articles.abstract: The weekly wrestling program will move to Netflix in 2025 as part of a 10-year agreement, a big leap into live events for the streaming platform.
articles.lead_paragraph: Netflix reached a multibillion-dollar, 10-year deal for exclusive rights to W.W.E.’s flagship weekly wrestling show, “Raw,” as the streaming giant broadens its offerings with more live content.
articles.byline: By Nicole Sperling and Gregory Schmidt
